body_text.text:
Recently Buckel and Stritzker $\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\mu\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\l$ using ion implantation at low temperatures found a peculiar instability in Pd-Ag-D alloys, in which a maximum $\\\\	au_{c}$ above 15 K could be achieved. This inatability looks like a break-off in previous superconductivity, at least above 1 K, with further implantation of D ions. So far the nature of this phenomenon is unknown.

We sugest here a mechanlsm explaining this result us a phase tranaition in the hydrogen sublattice, constructed by hydrogen, which occuples interstitial poeitions in the host alloy lattice.

Since the principle, equlvalent to Paull's princlple is realized in interatital solid solution $/ y$ , i.e. every interstitial sito can be occupied by one proton ( deuteron ) or none, the proton distribution function for interstitial sites has the form of a Fermi distribution:

After the formation of such a a superstructure, oquivalent in a disordered state interatiials are distinguished into "occupied" and "ireo" with a large onergy difference seemingly to be character-

There is an opinion /5/ that optic phonon modes take part in an eflective way in the attractive electron-elec-tron interaction leading to an enhancement in superconductivity. In this case the enhanced electron-phonon interaction munt lend to un overscreening of the proton-
becomes instable. $\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\Phi( \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\stackrel{\\\\ ullet} {\\\\ f R}+\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\stackrel{\\\\ ullet} {\\\\ f h}_{\\\\ f p} ) \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\,,$

A new aituation arises when an other solution of (1) and, hence, another superstructure corresponds the lowest free energy state. In this case the change of one solution for another will describe the phase transition in the hydrogen sublattice.

As faras $\\\\	au_{e}$ depende on the clectron-optic phonon interaction, it munt be sensitive to the variations in the hydrogen sublattice, which is responsible for this interaction.

The results of $/ y$ were used for the calculation of $\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\mathbf{\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\epsilon}$ , assuming that the implantation profile is independent of the isotope mass and of the bost lattice composition.

versus $\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\mathbb{H} ( \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\mathbb{D} )/$ M curves have some peculiarities which we think to be assoctat-ed with the phase transition in the hydrogen sublattice. In our opinion the type I phase

transition, caused by deuteron transler from octahedral to tetrahedral sites, takes
place in the D sublattice inside the Pd-Ag matrix, i.e. there Is formed a superetruc-ture, the localized mode of which do not participate in the electron-electron attractive interaction. Such a transier inside the Pd matrix is eaergetically unfavourable, because the proton zero-point amplitude is larger than that of the deuteroa, and the lattice
constant of Pd is less than that of Pd-Ag. Hence, the Pd-H order parameter, probably , changes continuously , and then the phase transition must be of type I.

An about 20 % drop in the residual resistance when superconductivity vaniahes in the Pd-Ag-D system is consistent with the above mechanism.

ln conclusion we would like to underline that Pd-noble metal-H(D) and Pd-H(D) alloys, probably , present a new clnas of compounds i which instability as well as high-lemperature superconductivity is driven by the optic phonon mode.
